title: Etihad Airways Signs $700 Million Deal with IBM
text:
By Rory Jones
DUBAI--Etihad Airways and IBM announced an information technology deal on Tuesday worth $700 million over 10 years that aims to improve the airline's operations and security, and cut costs from its network.
The agreement between Etihad and IBM includes analytics of customer data and the development of technology that can predict weather patterns to better manage the airline's flights at its Abu Dhabi hub.
About 100 Etihad staff will move to IBM, which will also develop and build a new data center in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates. The deal also covers Etihad's seven partner airlines in which it has bought minority stakes.
"We want to invest in innovation," Etihad's Chief Information and Technology Officer Robert Webb said in an interview. "We want technology to be pervasive throughout the business."
Government-owned Etihad signed the deal with IBM following a string of similar agreements with suppliers, such as Sabre Holdings Corp., SAP SE and Panasonic Avionics Corp., Mr. Webb said. The airline has negotiated products and services for all the carriers in which it holds minority stakes to cut costs, he added.
Etihad has spent hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years by purchasing minority stakes in other airlines and supporting their financing needs. To date, it has made non-controlling investments in eight airlines, including Italy's Alitalia, Germany's Air Berlin PLC and Jet Airways (India) Ltd.
IBM signed a similar deal with Deutsche Lufthansa AG in November last year worth EUR1 billion ($1.14 billion), which the German airline said would generate cost savings of EUR70 million a year.
"This is a movement across the industry," said Martin Jetter, senior vice president at IBM Global Technology Services. "You need an IT infrastructure that's available around the world and the applications and technology that allow the airline to find out the preferences of their guests."
Write to Rory Jones at rory.jones@wsj.com
Corrections & Amplifications
The deal also covers Etihad's seven partner airlines in which it has bought minority stakes. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated that Etihad has eight partner airlines in which it has bought minority stakes (Oct. 13, 2015).
